quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 4 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 4.4: Groups, Families, and Periods
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Periodic table organization and valence electrons

questions.question: Which of the following describes why elements in the same group share similar chemical properties?
options: They have the same number of valence electrons.
They have the same total number of electrons.
They are located in the same horizontal row.
They have the same mass number.
questions.explanation: Valence electrons determine how an atom bonds and reacts; since group members share this count, they exhibit similar chemical behavior.

questions.question: What does the period number ($n$) on the periodic table represent for the elements in that row?
options: The highest principal energy level occupied by electrons.
The total number of valence electrons.
The number of neutrons in the nucleus.
The total number of isotopes the element has.
questions.explanation: Each period represents a new 'shell' or principal energy level being filled as you move across the row.

questions.question: The 'Halogens' are a well-known chemical family. In which group are they located?
questions.explanation: Group 17 elements (F, Cl, Br, I, At) are known as the halogens and are highly reactive nonmetals.

questions.question: Which of these elements belongs to the 'Noble Gas' family?
questions.explanation: Neon ($Ne$) is in Group 18, characterized by a full valence shell and very low reactivity.

questions.question: Elements in Group 2 are collectively known as the:
questions.explanation: Group 2 contains elements like Magnesium and Calcium, which are known as the alkaline earth metals.

questions.question: As you move from top to bottom down a group, the atomic radius generally:
questions.explanation: Moving down a group adds more principal energy levels (shells), making the atom larger.

questions.question: Which element is considered part of Group 1 but is NOT an Alkali Metal?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen ($H$) is placed in Group 1 because it has one valence electron, but it is a nonmetal gas, not an alkali metal.

questions.question: The elements in Groups 3 through 12 are known as the:
questions.explanation: Groups 3-12 make up the d-block and are called the transition metals.

questions.question: What do all elements in Period 2 have in common regarding their electron configuration?
options: Their valence electrons are in the second principal energy level.
They all have two valence electrons.
They all have a full outer shell.
They all end in a 'p' orbital.
questions.explanation: The period number indicates that the second shell ($n=2$) is the highest energy level containing electrons.

questions.question: In the modern numbering system (1-18), which group contains the 'Alkali Metals'?
questions.explanation: Group 1 contains the alkali metals (excluding Hydrogen), which are the most reactive metals on the table.
